shared_text:
Washington State Department of Health
September 11 at 8:33 AM ·

Air quality has declined overnight and is currently unhealthy to hazardous in areas. Inhaling wildfire smoke is not good for anyone! Stay indoors and keep indoor air clean. A few tips...
➡️ Close your windows and doors to reduce intake of smoke. Open them when the air quality is good to refresh the air.
➡️ Avoid doing anything that may contribute to smoke or dust in the air, like burning candles or incense, smoking inside, frying or broiling, or vacuuming.
More tips at doh.wa.gov/smokefromfires.
Track air quality & wildfires at wasmoke.blogspot.com

Schools across the district kicked off the school year -- from Robert Eagle Staff MS, where students lined up for books and supplies and met with teachers and staff, to Rainier Beach High School where community came together for a back-to-school, drive-in BBQ.
This was also the beginning of our “Strong Start” week, Sept. 4-11. This week gives us time to test out technology, work out the issues, and focus on relationships and building community – all to ensure a smooth 2020-21 school year. While the vast majority of our students connected, logged in, and met new classmates, we also had a few bumps today.
We know that some students had difficulty logging in. Our tech team has worked to fix this and families were sent an email with more information this afternoon. Thank you for your patience and to all the school communities who came together to support one another and celebrate together. Learn more: https://www.seattleschools.org/district/calendars/news/what_s_new/technology_update

This effort started in March when staff configured over 10,000 district computers to distribute to students. SPS also partnered with Amazon to deliver 8,200 new computers to elementary students. In total, close to 50% of SPS students received a device this spring. The district has placed three large orders of computers this summer and staff are in the process of planning technology distribution events before school begins. Yesterday, Superintendent Juneau released a statement announcing that Seattle Public Schools will enact a district-wide one-year suspension of the four SPD School Emphasis Officers and one SPD School Resource Officer in our schools. A resolution will also be put forth by the Seattle School Board to reevaluate this program in our schools. SPD will not be present on our campuses except in emergencies.
The anti-Black systems in place in this country are deeply rooted and have been fortified over hundreds of years. The work to tear down and re-build these systems is complex. We will re-evaluate the presence of SPD in our buildings, but like any other organization that supports our students within our walls, they must be aligned to our strategic plan Seattle Excellence, and work to uphold and support the inherent brilliance and innocence in each of our students. Read more here: https://www.seattleschools.org/district/calendars/news/what_s_new/school_emphasis_officers

Last night, we learned that SPD, SWAT, and the National Guard used Seattle Public Schools property as a staging area in their response to protests. We did not give permission, nor condone, the use of SPS property for staging of militarized police or actual military.

Our school buildings should be safe, welcoming places for students to learn. While schools are closed, many of the spaces militarized police occupied are used for distribution of meals, learning packets, books, and health resources. These are spaces for student learning and supports, not for militarized responses.

Superintendent Juneau has contacted SPD and informed them that they may not use our parking lots or school buildings to stage SWAT and the National Guard, and has been assured that this will not happen again.

Public Health - Seattle & King County
May 11 at 3:00 PM ·

Starting May 18, King County residents are directed to wear face coverings in most public settings.

Wear a face covering when you are at any indoor or outdoor public space where you may be within 6 feet of someone who does not live with you.

A face covering is not needed when you are outside walking, exercising, or otherwise outdoors if you are able to regularly stay 6 feet away from other people who do not live with you.

Visit kingcounty.gov/masks to learn more and find information about face coverings in additional languages.

SPS TV will continue to broadcast teacher lessons until the end of the school year for students to access via cable tv, on the SPS website, and on YouTube. However, in alignment with OSPI guidelines for remote learning, the broadcast schedule will be changing starting Monday, April 27 in order to support sustainable and educational programming.

We will run content on our tv station for K-5 students every morning, Monday-Friday, from 9:00am-11:30am. Subjects will continue to include ELA, Physical Education, Science, Math, Arts, and Washington State Tribal History. Social Emotional Learning videos will be added to the weekly broadcast schedule as well, per OPSI guidance. Middle School and High School science videos will also be available on the website.

In the afternoons, we will run additional content as we receive it. This content will include videos for Special Education, The Creative Advantage, African American History Museum, Middle School Science, and more. Learn more: https://www.seattleschools.org/district/calendars/news/what_s_new/coronavirus_update/resources/sps_tv

Today, Governor Inslee made an emergency proclamation extending the closure of all schools through the end of the school year. As a result, Seattle Public Schools will not reopen our school buildings for the 2019-20 school year as we had hoped.

While our buildings remain closed, we will continue to provide essential supports and services for students and families. Thank you for your patience and grace as we transition again and begin to address what the Governor’s order means for our SPS community now and as we look to next fall. We will share more information in the coming days about what this extended closure means for staff and students, including graduation for seniors and students receiving specialized services.
